result.execSummary:
This case has not been concluded. Unless a judgment of conviction is entered, the defendant is presumed innocent of all charges.

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

8:47 AM Prosecuting attorney Benjamin Lindsay appeared in court for the State of Wisconsin, Defendant Kendarrius Keshaun Willard appeared in court, in custody, Attorney Joseph Reback for Kendarrius Keshaun Willard appeared in court. Testimony of Deputy Van Pamel. State rests. No witnesses by Defense. State moves for bind over without argument. Defense moves to dismiss without argument. Court makes findings, finds probable cause, and binds matter over for trial. State files the information. Counsel requests date for arraignment. Defendant to be in person for next hearing.
Arraignment scheduled for April 5, 2022 at 08:15 am.
Arraignment on April 5, 2022 at 08:15 am.

Counsel waives reading of amended complaint. Court advises charges/penalties of added charge and finds probable cause. Counsel requests time to review preliminary hearing waiver with Defendant.
